results.title: Dr. Eric Cassell, Bioethicist Who Put the Patient First, Dies at 93
results.abstract: A professor and prolific author, he cautioned that doctors too often focus on the disease instead of the overall well-being of the sufferer.

multimedia.caption: The medical ethicist Dr. Eric Cassell in 2013. He was at the forefront of efforts to emphasize palliative care in treating patients.
The medical ethicist Dr. Eric Cassell in 2013. He was at the forefront of efforts to emphasize palliative care in treating patients.

results.title: ‘Lurching Between Crisis and Complacency’: Was This Our Last Covid Surge?
results.abstract: Rising immunity and modest changes in behavior may explain why cases are declining, but much remains unknown, scientists say.

multimedia.caption: Vaccinations at the Unidos En Salud community vaccination and testing site in San Francisco this summer. Infections are down more than 40 percent since August.

results.title: The Most Important Global Meeting You’ve Probably Never Heard Of Is Now
results.abstract: Countries are gathering in an effort to stop a biodiversity collapse that scientists say could equal climate change as an existential crisis.

United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change

results.title: Data From Federal Scientists Raise Questions About J.&J. Booster Shots
results.abstract: People who have received the company’s one-shot vaccine may benefit from a booster with another brand. F.D.A. advisers will discuss the data on Friday.

results.title: 2021 Has Been a Bad Year for Manatees
results.abstract: Manatees in Florida have been dying at an alarming rate, with the state losing about 10 percent of its population in just a year.

results.title: Back on Earth, Shatner and Bezos have a Kirk-Spock moment.
results.abstract: After the Blue Origin crew set down, science fiction met reality.

multimedia.caption: “We say, ‘Oh that’s blue sky.’ And then suddenly you shoot through it and all of a sudden, like you whip the sheet off you when you’re asleep, you’re looking into blackness,” Mr. Shatner said Wednesday.
multimedia.copyright: Blue Origin, via EPA, via Shutterstock

results.title: The W.H.O. names an advisory group to study the origins of the pandemic.
results.abstract: The group includes scientists from 26 countries, a reflection of the W.H.O.’s effort to amass widespread international support for the work.

multimedia.caption: Dominic Dwyer, a member of a since-disbanded World Health Organization team that investigated the origins of the coronavirus, arriving at the Wuhan Institute of Virology in China, in February.

results.title: Many ‘Star Trek’ fans are eager to see William Shatner boldly go to space.
results.abstract: The series’ longtime viewers said they were excited to see the man who played Captain Kirk make science fiction seem a bit more real.

results.title: F.D.A. Issues Guidelines to Reduce Salt in Foods
results.abstract: The new recommendations are aimed at food manufacturers and restaurants. Some experts say they don’t go far enough.

multimedia.caption: Some of the excess sodium in the American diet comes from meals served at restaurants. The F.D.A. is asking businesses and food suppliers to cut the use of salt in the foods they sell.

results.title: Private Equity Funds, Sensing Profit in Tumult, Are Propping Up Oil
results.abstract: These secretive investment companies have pumped billions of dollars into fossil fuel projects, buying up offshore platforms, building new pipelines and extending lifelines to coal power plants.

multimedia.caption: According to new research, private equity firms have invested at least $1.1 trillion into the energy sector since 2010.
According to new research, private equity firms have invested at least $1.1 trillion into the energy sector since 2010.

results.title: Fossil-Fuel Use Could Peak in Just a Few Years. Still, Major Challenges Loom.
results.abstract: The world has made progress in the fight against climate change, with wind, solar and other clean technologies taking off. But more is needed to avert catastrophe, a new report finds.

multimedia.caption: A coal-fired power plant in western Germany. Since World War II, global carbon emissions have been on a seemingly inexorable upward trajectory, but a turning point is in sight, according to the world’s top energy agency.

A coal-fired power plant in western Germany. Since World War II, global carbon emissions have been on a seemingly inexorable upward trajectory, but a turning point is in sight, according to the world’s top energy agency.

results.title: F.D.A. Authorizes E-Cigarettes to Stay on U.S. Market for the First Time
results.abstract: The agency approved three Vuse vaping products and said their benefits in helping smokers quit outweighed the risks of hooking youths.
results.byline: By Matt Richtel and Sheila Kaplan

multimedia.caption: The Vuse Solo e-cigarette is the first to be approved for market by the F.D.A., which says it helps smokers quit.

results.title: Did a Meteor Explode Over New Hampshire? That May Explain the Boom.
results.abstract: Meteorologists said that a bolide, a type of large meteor explosion in the atmosphere, might have been the source of a disturbance that was widely reported on Sunday.

multimedia.caption: A mysterious boom was heard in New Hampshire and parts of Massachusetts on Sunday afternoon.

results.title: After 2 Years, a Tire Is Removed From an Elk’s Neck in Colorado
results.abstract: Wildlife officials had been seeking the elk since it was first spotted in 2019. On Saturday, they tranquilized the animal and slid the tire off after removing its antlers.

multimedia.caption: The elk with the tire around its neck was first spotted in 2019 by a Colorado wildlife officer who was conducting a survey of bighorn sheep and mountain goats in the Mount Evans Wilderness.

results.title: Martin Sherwin, Prize-winning Biographer of Oppenheimer, Dies at 84
results.abstract: A historian of the nuclear age, he and his co-author, Kai Bird, won a 2006 Pulitzer for their book about the scientist behind the atom bomb.

multimedia.caption: Martin Sherwin, a history professor, spent 20 years researching the life of J. Robert Oppenheimer, the atomic bomb’s creator. Then he met a co-author, Kai Bird (right), and they produced their biography in 2005.

results.title: Aspirin Use to Prevent 1st Heart Attack or Stroke Should Be Curtailed, U.S. Panel Says
results.abstract: Adults at high risk for cardiovascular disease may face serious side effects if they start a daily regimen of low-dose aspirin.
org_facet: Agency for Healthcare Research and Quality
United States Preventive Services Task Force

multimedia.caption: Doctors would be discouraged from starting patients on a daily dose of baby aspirin to prevent heart attack or stroke under proposed new guidelines.
Doctors would be discouraged from starting patients on a daily dose of baby aspirin to prevent heart attack or stroke under proposed new guidelines.

results.title: One Woman Won a Nobel This Year. Quotas Aren’t the Answer, an Official Says.
results.abstract: Only one of the 13 laureates this year was a woman, but the head of the Royal Swedish Academy of Sciences dismissed the idea of guaranteeing representation.

multimedia.caption: The journalist Maria Ressa was the only woman to be awarded a Nobel Prize in 2021.
The journalist Maria Ressa was the only woman to be awarded a Nobel Prize in 2021.

results.title: A Designer Who Finds Beauty in Decay
results.abstract: In a Warsaw warehouse, Marcin Rusak turns decomposing plant material into polished pieces that degrade over time.
results.byline: By Stephen Wallis and Rafal Milach

multimedia.caption: The designer Marcin Rusak in his Warsaw studio. Behind him is a Flora tabletop (2017); in the foreground are dried plants he uses, including beech, pear tree, ash-leaved maple, eucalyptus and others.
